description: a(n) = number of primes of the form k*(n-k) + 1.
comments: Number of primes of form x*y+1 with x+y=n.
example: a(7) = 3, 1*6 +1 = 7, 2*5 +1 = 11, 3*4 +1 = 13.n=16: {m: m=x*y+1 and x+y=16} = {16,29,40,49,56,61,64,65} containing two primes: 29 and 61, therefore a(16)=2.n = 7 is the only number which gives primes for all possible values of k.
author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jan 27 2004
extensions: Edited by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Aug 23 2008 at the suggestion of R. J. Mathar
